task_1.title: Conduct User Interviews
task_1.description: Interview 3 users to understand their pain points around a specific experience (e.g., commuting, recycling, childcare).
examples: Example 1: Ask commuters about their daily transportation frustrations.
Example 2: Interview gig workers about challenges accessing affordable workspaces.

task_2.title: Root Cause Analysis with the 5 Whys
task_2.description: Use the 5 Whys technique to uncover the root cause of a problem identified in interviews.
examples: Example: Why do users avoid public transport? → Overcrowding → Why? → Limited buses → Why? → Budget constraints.

task_3.title: Craft a Problem Statement
task_3.description: Synthesize interview insights into a clear problem statement using the [User] needs a way to [need], but [insight] template.
examples: Example: Parents need a way to find affordable childcare in urban areas, but options are scarce and unregulated.

task_4.title: Brainstorm Creative Solutions
task_4.description: Generate 3-5 solutions for the problem statement. Focus on quantity over quality.
examples: Example: A community-based childcare co-op for gig workers.

task_5.title: Build a Low-Fidelity Prototype
task_5.description: Create a simple prototype (e.g., paper sketch, role-play, digital wireframe) of your top solution.
examples: Example: Simulate a carpooling service using WhatsApp groups.

task_6.title: Test Prototype with Users
task_6.description: Gather feedback on your prototype by asking: 'What works?' and 'What doesn't?'
examples: Example: Users say your recycling app needs a reward system → Add a points feature.

task_7.title: Map a Business Model Canvas
task_7.description: Sketch a Business Model Canvas for your idea, covering 9 components: Customer Segments, Value Proposition, Channels, etc.
examples: Example: A subscription model for motorcycle taxis in high-demand areas.

task_8.title: Test Pricing Assumptions
task_8.description: Run a small experiment (e.g., free trial, A/B test) to validate if users will pay for your solution.
examples: Example: Offer a 7-day free trial of your app and track conversion rates.

task_9.title: Identify Market Opportunities/Threats
task_9.description: List one opportunity (e.g., rising demand for solar products) and one threat (e.g., new import tariffs) for your business.
examples: Example: Opportunity: Growing interest in eco-friendly packaging. Threat: Cheap plastic alternatives flooding the market.

task_10.title: Craft a Business Pitch
task_10.description: Write a 3-sentence pitch using the Before-After-Bridge framework.
examples: Example: Before: Workers waste hours commuting. After: Affordable shared vans save time. Bridge: Our app connects riders with verified drivers.

task_11.title: Achieve Product-Market Fit
task_11.description: Conduct user interviews, build an MVP, and test it with users to validate Product-Market Fit.
examples: Example: Interview 5 users about their pain points, build a simple app prototype, and test it with 10 users.

task_12.title: Align Your Product with the Right Channels
task_12.description: Research user behavior and test different channels to achieve Market-Channel Fit.
examples: Example: Test social media ads, email campaigns, and partnerships to see which channel drives the most engagement.

task_13.title: Ensure Channel-Model Fit
task_13.description: Calculate CAC and ARPU for each channel to ensure profitability and alignment with your revenue model.
examples: Example: Compare the cost of acquiring users via Facebook ads with the revenue they generate.

task_14.title: Align Your Revenue Model with Market Behavior
task_14.description: Test pricing models and gather feedback to achieve Model-Market Fit.
examples: Example: Offer a free trial and tiered pricing to see which model resonates with your market.

task_15.title: Craft a Growth Strategy
task_15.description: Summarize your Product-Market Fit, Market-Channel Fit, Channel-Model Fit, and Model-Market Fit into a clear growth strategy.
examples: Example: Define your target users, choose the most effective channels, and align your pricing model with market behavior.

task_16.title: Map Emotional Triggers
task_16.description: Identify how emotions (e.g., FOMO, trust) influence user behavior for your product.
examples: Example: A farming app uses progress bars (motivation) and community leaderboards (FOMO).

task_17.title: Apply the Hooked Model
task_17.description: Design triggers, actions, rewards, and investments for your product.
examples: Example: Trigger: Anxiety about savings. Action: Logging expenses. Reward: Financial health insights. Investment: Custom budgets.

task_18.title: Analyze User Ability/Motivation
task_18.description: Use BJ Fogg's model to simplify user actions (e.g., one-click signup) or boost motivation (e.g., progress bars).
examples: Example: Reduce effort for a recycling app by adding barcode scanning for waste categories.

task_19.title: Scope a Work Package
task_19.description: Define deliverables and purpose for a project (e.g., 'Develop a carpooling app prototype to reduce commute costs').
examples: Example: Deliverables: App wireframe, user manual. Purpose: Cut commute expenses by 40% for urban workers.

task_20.title: Create Milestones
task_20.description: Break your project into 4 weekly milestones (e.g., Week 1: Research, Week 2: Design).
examples: Example: Week 1: User interviews → Week 2: Prototype v1 → Week 3: Test with users → Week 4: Iterate & launch.

task_21.title: Define Actionable Tasks
task_21.description: Break milestones into specific tasks (e.g., 'Sketch 3 app screens').
examples: Example: Task 1: Survey 10 users → Task 2: Sketch app screens → Task 3: Build WhatsApp prototype.

task_22.title: Prioritize Tasks
task_22.description: Focus on what matters most. Use frameworks like the Eisenhower Matrix to categorize tasks based on urgency and importance.
examples: Example: Fix login errors (Urgent/Important) vs. Design new icons (Not Urgent/Not Important).

task_23.title: Create Weekly Sprints
task_23.description: Plan tasks into weekly sprints (e.g., Monday: User interviews, Tuesday: Prototype edits).
examples: Example: Monday: User interviews (2hrs) → Tuesday: Prototype edits (1hr) → Wednesday: Feedback session (1hr).

task_24.title: Review and Reflect
task_24.description: At the end of each week, reflect on progress, challenges, and improvements.
examples: Example: Completed: Interviewed 3 users. Challenges: Recruiting testers. Improvements: Partner with a local community.
